title: Case Study: Achilles Tendonitis in a Recreational Runner
clinical_history: A 35-year-old male recreational runner presents with a 3-week history of pain and stiffness in the posterior aspect of his right ankle. He reports a gradual onset of symptoms, which have worsened over time, particularly with running and jumping activities. The patient has been running 3 times a week for the past year, but recently increased his mileage and intensity. He experiences pain and stiffness in the morning, which improves with activity, but worsens with prolonged running.
aggrevating_factors: Running, jumping, hiking, and calf raises
picture: A 24-hour picture of the patient's symptoms shows that the pain is worse in the morning (7-8/10) and improves to 4-5/10 after 10-15 minutes of activity. However, with prolonged running or activity, the pain returns to 6-8/10.
past_history: Previous ankle sprain 2 years ago, which was managed conservatively. No previous history of tendonitis or similar conditions.
medical_history: Generally healthy, with no significant medical conditions. No history of steroid use or fluoroquinolone antibiotics.
medications: Ibuprofen 400mg prn for pain and inflammation
personal_history: Married with two children. Works as an accountant in a small firm. Enjoys running and hiking in his free time.
imaging: Ultrasound imaging of the Achilles tendon shows tendinosis and mild swelling, but no rupture.
